awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: COLLAB: Optimal Design of Robust Compliant Actuators for Ubiquitous Co-Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
Motion of robotic devices is achieved by enabling the movement of its joints by devices called actuators.  This National Robotics Initiative (NRI) project seeks to understand how to design compliant actuators  for human-interactive robots that are energy-efficient and safe across a wide variety of tasks and situations. Unlike rigid actuators, compliant actuators can store and release mechanical energy for greater efficiency and absorb shocks for greater safety, which has made them especially popular in wearable robots (i.e., prostheses and exoskeletons). However, the compliant element of the actuator (e.g., a spring between the motor and the robot joint) must be carefully chosen to achieve these benefits, which has restricted previous implementations to specific use cases. The mathematical framework in this project will enable design of compliant actuators that change their physical properties to guarantee safety and efficiency as interactions vary from gentle to forceful. Compliant actuators that are robust to a wide range of conditions can be used for many applications, allowing mass production at lower cost. The energy efficiency of these actuators will increase the battery range of mobile co-robots and allow the use of smaller, lighter batteries in wearable robots. This work is significant to the ubiquity of compliant actuator technology for safe, energy-efficient interactions between robots and humans in uncertain real-world situations outside the laboratory.

This project will establish a robust convex optimization framework for designing series elastic actuators (SEAs) that globally minimize electrical energy consumption while satisfying actuator/safety constraints. When designing an SEA, a parametric representation of the elastic element (e.g., the stiffness of a linear spring) is typically optimized for a single task (trajectory and load). However, this paradigm has two key limitations: 1) solutions are only optimal within the given space of parameters, and 2) the benefits of the elasticity (i.e., efficiency and compliance) can be entirely lost outside of specific operating conditions. A nonlinear series elastic element can potentially solve these problems by providing different stiffness characteristics at different operating points, but the ideal parameterization of the spring is unknown. A non-parametric, robust optimization framework is therefore needed to develop SEA technology that can achieve a variety of tasks in a variety of situations (customizability) for ubiquitous interaction with humans (scalability). Tools exist to solve convex optimization problems with uncertainty in their parameters, but the design of SEAs is not currently known to be a convex problem. The overall goals of this project are then to 1) understand the convexity of SEA energy consumption as a function of stiffness characteristics, 2) understand how to design nonlinear series elastic elements to achieve maximal efficiency while satisfying constraints, and 3) understand how to design SEAs that are robust to uncertainties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
The overall goals of the project were to develop a design architecture that when coupled with an optimization anaysis, could lead to designs of series-elastic actuators that require less electrical energy across applications. This work was a collaborative project with Prof. Robert Gregg, and my contribution was the design of linear and non-linear springs that are small, lightweight, and accurate. Through this effort, we have produced a new type of two-part torsion spring that is the lightest and smallest every produced (to our knowledge). We developed three types of springs, namely, linear, serpentine, and non-linear springs. The springs are planar, and can be easily manufactured and implemented in robots across application domains.  We have already included these springs in the development of our Open-Source Robotic Leg (www.opensourceleg.com), which was developed under a previous NSF NRI award (PI Rouse).

We have detailed our design in two (submitted) publications, and have developed an open-source design tool that automatically designs springs in minutes. We are releasing our design tool to the academic community, which we believe will foster use of our noval spring design by other researchers. When compared to previously designed springs in the robotics literature, our design tool produced springs that were smaller and lighter in each case, potentially contributing to designs that are more energy efficient through lower mass, inertia, and volume constraints.

This work has fostered the training of several PhD students and a postdoctoral fellow (Dr. Gray Thomas). Both the doctoral students and fellow were able to travel and present their work at national and international conferences (including upcoming ICRA 2023). The spring design and development was included in two courses taught at the University of Michigan by PI Rouse.  The design was discussed in the context of innnovations in wearable robotic systems, as well as flexure design in his most recent course (ROB 311: How to build robots and make them move). Finally, the project was presented at numerous national an international seminars and different universities and companies.  Most recently, the project was presented at (Google) X.

Project references:

Z Bons, G C Thomas, L M Mooney, and E J Rouse. A Compact, Two-Part Torsion Spring Architecture. Proceedings of the 2023 International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA). In review.

Z Bons, G C Thomas, L M Mooney, and E J Rouse. The scalable design of a two-part rotary spring architecture. IEEE Transactions on Mechatronics. In review.

U H Lee, T Shepherd, S Kim, A De, H Su, R D Gregg, L M Mooney, and E J Rouse. How to Model Brushless Electric Motors for the Design of Lightweight Robotic Systems (Tutorial), awaiting resubmission.

E Bolivar-Nieto, G C Thomas, E J Rouse, and R D Gregg. Convex Optimization for Spring Design in Series Elastic  Actuators: From Theory to Practice. Proceedings of the IEEE Conference of Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS).  pp. 9327-9332, 2021


Last Modified: 12/15/2022
Modified by: Elliott J Rouse

por.por_txt_cntn:
The overall goals of the project were to develop a design  architecture that when coupled with an optimization anaysis, could lead  to designs of series-elastic actuators that require less electrical  energy across applications. This work was a collaborative project with  Prof. Robert Gregg, and my contribution was the design of linear and non-linear springs  that are small, lightweight, and accurate. Through this effort, we have  produced a new type of two-part torsion spring that is the lightest and  smallest every produced (to our knowledge). We developed three types of springs, namely,  linear, serpentine, and non-linear springs. The springs are planar, and  can be easily manufactured and implemented in robots across application  domains.  We have already included these springs in the development of  our Open-Source Robotic Leg (www.opensourceleg.com), which was developed  under a previous NSF NRI award (PI Rouse). 

We have detailed our design  in two (submitted) publications, and have developed an open-source  design tool that automatically designs springs in minutes. We are  releasing our design tool to the academic community, which we believe  will foster use of our noval spring design by other researchers. When compared to previously designed springs in the robotics literature, our design tool produced  springs that were smaller and lighter in each case, potentially contributing to  designs that are more energy efficient through lower mass, inertia, and  volume constraints.

This work has fostered the training of several  PhD students and a postdoctoral fellow (Dr. Gray Thomas). Both the  doctoral students and fellow were able to travel and present their work  at national and international conferences (including upcoming ICRA  2023). The spring design and development was included in two courses  taught at the University of Michigan by PI Rouse.  The design was  discussed in the context of innnovations in wearable robotic systems, as  well as flexure design in his most recent course (ROB 311: How to build  robots and make them move). Finally, the project was presented at  numerous national an international seminars and different universities  and companies.  Most recently, the project was presented at (Google) X.

Project references:
 

Z Bons, G C Thomas, L M Mooney, and E J Rouse. A Compact, Two-Part Torsion Spring Architecture. Proceedings of the 2023 International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA). In review.
  

Z Bons, G C Thomas, L M Mooney, and E J Rouse. The scalable design of a two-part rotary spring architecture. IEEE Transactions on Mechatronics. In review.

U H Lee, T Shepherd, S Kim, A De, H Su, R D Gregg, L M Mooney, and E J Rouse. How to Model Brushless Electric Motors for the Design of Lightweight Robotic Systems (Tutorial), awaiting resubmission.
 

E Bolivar-Nieto, G C Thomas, E J Rouse, and R D Gregg. Convex Optimization for Spring Design in Series Elastic  Actuators: From Theory to Practice. Proceedings of the IEEE Conference of Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS).  pp. 9327-9332, 2021
